speaker: FIRST SERVANT
content: He complains that Potpan is not helping clear the tables, sarcastically noting that carrying or scraping a trencher (wooden plate) is too much for him.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: He remarks that when only one or two men do all the work, and they are unwashed, it is a disgusting situation.

speaker: FIRST SERVANT
content: He orders the removal of join-stools (simple stools) and the court-cupboard (sideboard), asks someone to save him a piece of marchpane (marzipan), and to let in Susan Grindstone and Nell, calling for Antony and Potpan.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: He simply replies 'Yes, boy, ready.'

speaker: FIRST SERVANT
content: He tells them they are being asked for in the great chamber.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: He says they cannot be in two places at once, urges everyone to be cheerful and brisk, and uses the proverb 'the longer liver take all' (the survivor gets everything).

speaker: CAPULET
content: He welcomes the guests, teasing that ladies without corns should dance, and those who hesitate (make dainty) must have corns. He nostalgically recalls his own masked dancing days, now gone, and calls for music and dancing. He then orders more light, tables put away, and the fire quenched because the room is hot, expressing pleasure at the unexpected fun.

speaker: CAPULET'S COUSIN
content: He swears by the Virgin Mary (By’r Lady) that it has been thirty years.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He disagrees, saying it was only twenty-five years ago at Lucentio’s wedding, and they wore masks then.

speaker: CAPULET'S COUSIN
content: He insists it was longer, since Lucentio’s son is now thirty.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He refuses to believe it, saying the son was only a ward (minor under guardianship) two years ago.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks who the lady is that the knight is holding hands with.

speaker: SERVANT
content: He replies that he does not know.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He exclaims that her beauty outshines the torches, comparing her to a jewel in an Ethiopian’s ear and a dove among crows. He vows to touch her hand after the dance and renounces his past loves, declaring this his first sight of true beauty. This speech marks his instant infatuation with Juliet.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Recognizing Romeo’s voice as a Montague, he calls for his rapier, accusing Romeo of coming masked (antic face) to mock (fleer) their celebration. He swears by his family’s honor that killing him would be justified. This shows the immediate threat of violence.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He questions why Tybalt is so enraged.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt alerts his uncle Capulet that Romeo, a Montague enemy, has come to their feast out of spite to mock their celebration. This establishes the immediate threat of violence and Tybalt's hot-headed nature.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet asks for confirmation that the intruder is young Romeo, showing he recognizes the name and perhaps knows Romeo's reputation.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt confirms it is indeed Romeo, whom he calls a villain, reinforcing his anger and desire for confrontation.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet tells Tybalt to calm down and leave Romeo alone, noting he behaves like a dignified gentleman and that Verona considers him virtuous. He insists that as host he won't allow any insult to a guest in his house, demanding Tybalt show a pleasant face instead of scowling. This reveals Capulet's authority and unexpected tolerance toward Romeo.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt insists such a villain deserves a hostile reception and declares he will not tolerate Romeo's presence, defying Capulet's order.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Enraged, Capulet asserts his authority, calling Tybalt 'goodman boy' (a belittling term) and insisting Romeo will be tolerated. He accuses Tybalt of trying to start a mutiny and 'set cock-a-hoop' (cause disorder) among the guests. This outburst shows Capulet's temper and determination to keep peace at his feast.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt protests that it is shameful to allow Romeo to remain, still resisting his uncle's command.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet escalates his rebuke, calling Tybalt a saucy (insolent) boy and warning that his defiance may scathe (harm) him. He calls Tybalt a princox (an impertinent youth) and orders him to be quiet, while also calling for more light and cheer to restore the festive mood, showing he's trying to manage both Tybalt and the party.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt says being forced to be patient while filled with anger makes him tremble. He will withdraw now, but predicts this intrusion that seems harmless will turn bitterly poisonous later. This foreshadows future conflict and Tybalt's vengeful plans.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo addresses Juliet with a metaphor comparing her to a holy shrine and himself to a pilgrim. He says if his hand profanes her, his lips are like two blushing pilgrims ready to atone with a gentle kiss. This begins their poetic, religiously-inflected courtship.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet plays along with the metaphor, saying he undervalues his hand, which shows polite devotion. She notes that saints allow pilgrims to touch their hands, and that palm-to-palm contact is the holy kiss of pilgrims (palmers). She cleverly deflects the kiss while continuing the religious wordplay.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks if saints and pilgrims don't also have lips, pushing his argument for a kiss.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet replies that yes, pilgrims and saints have lips—but for prayer, subtly maintaining her resistance while staying within the metaphor.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo pleads that just as hands pray, so should lips; he asks her to grant his prayer (a kiss) so his faith doesn't turn to despair. This cleverly turns religious devotion into romantic pursuit.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says saints do not move, though they grant prayers, giving a coy permission for him to kiss her while she remains still.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says then she should not move while he receives the effect of his prayer, and claims that by kissing her, his sin is purged. This completes their witty exchange and leads to their first kiss.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet playfully suggests that if Romeo has taken a sin from her lips by kissing her, then her own lips must now possess that sin. This continues their flirtatious exchange about their first kiss.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo delights in her witty framing of their kiss as a sin, calling it a sweetly presented offense, and asks her to return his 'sin' by kissing him again.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet remarks that Romeo kisses according to the rules, meaning expertly or conventionally, possibly with a hint of teasing.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse interrupts to say Juliet's mother wants to speak with her, moving the plot and separating the lovers.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks who Juliet's mother is, showing his sudden concern about her family identity.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse explains that her mother is the lady of the house, a good and virtuous woman, and that she herself nursed Juliet. She adds that whoever marries Juliet will have plenty of money ('the chinks').

speaker: ROMEO
content: Horrified, Romeo realizes Juliet is a Capulet, his family's enemy. He exclaims that his life is now owed to his foe, meaning his love binds him to an enemy.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges Romeo to leave because the party is at its peak and it's time to go.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees but says his anxiety only grows, as he now knows Juliet's identity.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet insists the guests stay for a light meal ('banquet'), but when they leave, he thanks them and calls for torches, noting by his faith ('by my fay') that it's getting late and he'll go to bed.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks the Nurse to identify a gentleman across the room, beginning her inquiry about Romeo.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse mistakenly identifies him as the son and heir of old Tiberio (likely a misremembrance or error for another guest).

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks about another man leaving, trying to pinpoint Romeo without naming him.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says that one is probably young Petruchio, again giving a wrong name.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks about the one who followed and wouldn't dance, clearly describing Romeo.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says she doesn't know, leaving Juliet without the answer she seeks and increasing dramatic tension.

speaker: JULIET
content: She tells the Nurse to find out his name, and says that if he is married, her grave will be her wedding bed—meaning she will die unmarried.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse reports that his name is Romeo, a Montague, the only son of their great enemy.

speaker: JULIET
content: She laments that her only love comes from her only hate; she saw him too early without knowing who he was, and now knows too late. This is a monstrous or unnatural birth of love to her, that she must love a hated enemy.

speaker: NURSE
content: She repeats 'What’s this?' in surprise, asking what Juliet is saying.

speaker: JULIET
content: She dismisses her outburst as a rhyme she just learned from someone she danced with, hiding her true feelings.

speaker: NURSE
content: She calls back 'Right away!' to someone offstage, then tells Juliet they should leave because all the guests have gone.
